summary.body: We've just come back from a lovely first visit to the Wood Street Restaurant and Bar. Gorgeous food, great service, wonderful setting.  When it came to paying the bill, we asked if we could pay the main part with a card but pay the service charge in cash to ensure the staff get it. We have no problem excercising this legal right in other restaurants. You may or may not be aware but whenever the service charge is paid with a card, the staff do not get it but the corporation who owns the restaurant does. Time Out Magazine wrote a piece about a year ago stating that if you want to ensure the staff who served you are rewarded with a tip, then pay the service charge in cash. Our friendly and efficient waitress asked the manager on our behalf if we could do this, but she refused. We HAD to pay it with the card.  We were shocked that the manager refused point blankly and didn't even come over to explain why but decided not to go any further, we had a lovely meal in wonderful surroundings but ended up paying the waitress some more on top of the service charge as we left, just because we felt so bad for her.  She seemed to have no idea that she was entitled to the service charge. At St Paul's Chez Gerard, our regular haunt we often pay the service charge in cash and it goes directly to the staff. NB: the manager of the Wood Street Bar is the daughter of one of the three owners, who also own other restaurants, which is probably why she didn't want the staff to get the tips but her father's company instead. When we go next week, we'll have to point blankly refuse to pay the service charge with a card or bring extra cash. I understand Wood Street Restaurant is very popular with us Barbican residents on Sundays. May I suggest, if you'd like the service charge to go to the staff (and not just the manager's family and business partners), that you consider paying it in cash and ask for this right if they refuse you. We will, as otherwise, there's no incentive for good service.  In other London restaurants (and other parts of the world, especially the States) , waiters and waitresses thrive on their good tips, it's a shame that their right to this has been eroded at our local.  Has anyone else experienced the same problem at the Wood Street or any other local restaurants?
summary.subject: Tips at the Wood Street Restaurant and Bar

summary.body: 0620 on a Sunday morning is -not- the time to be racing cars around a residential building! Is anyone else awake? People have been driving up and down the tunnel at at least 60mph in clusters; some with modified exhaust pipes that make them sound like mopeds. After twenty minutes or so, the circuit seemed to be extended to include Aldersgate as well. I tried COL police non-emergency number, but no answer. It just rings and rings. I'm not even sure; is there actually any law broken if they drive around in circles in a residential area? Other than speeding, I mean. It's happened before quite a few times.  I felt rather pleased a few months ago when one of them, whilst speeding outrageously through the tunnel, burst a tyre on the kerb. No damage done except for the tyre; it seemed like just deserts so I allowed myself a small smile. Sadly, there was no such luck today. I wouldn't mind terribly much if they did it during the day, but it's only ever between 0100 and 0730 in the morning. Which is rather antisocial. I want to go back to sleep and when I started writing this message after an hour it seemed to have calmed down, but they are back again now. 0620 to 0715 so far.
summary.subject: Tunnel-racing

summary.body: While we're on the subject of planning applications, there has been one made for the "Void Space" at the base of Cromwell Tower to be turned into a flat. I mention this as a recent flyer in Cromwell informed that the applicant is already a Cromwell Tower resident...and is also a member of the Cromwell Tower House Group. I would not want to comment on the rights and wrongs of the above, suffice to say that given the huge demand for tower flats, perhaps interested parties would like to contact the Chair of Cromwell Tower sub group, John Tomlinson, to evaluate the proposal. Apparently he is also liasing with David Graves of the BA. My personal view is that either the space should be converted into an apartment for a local key worker (teacher, nurse etc) plus family*, or auctioned by the corporation to the highest bidder with the resultant sum being spent on residential amenities. Either way, there should be more visibility as I suspect non-Cromwellians have not been informed of this. M * I should point out that I have no idea if the applicant - who is named on the flyer - is actually a key worker. For all I know, he might be. For that matter, he might also have already won an auction.
summary.subject: Cromwell Tower new flat being created - planning application

summary.body: Is it me, or is the mosquito situation getting out of hand. I have never been bitten in my life before, but last week i awoke thinking i was having a bad dream - i thought i'd heard a buzzing in my ear. I lay there, just as i was going off to sleep, it happened again. And then again. then i felt something crawling over my face. I jumped out of bed, couldn't see anything, went back. This happened continuously throughout the night and drove me mad. In the morning... big red bite marks everywhere. then searched my room and found a mosquito, bloated with what i presume was my blood. squashed it, blood everywhere. Since then i have found dozens each day in my flat. It's driving me crazy. What's going on? i don't even live particuarly near the lakes. Help! I don't want to get mosguito nets for my windows, but i don't remember it being like this last year. I do remember though there being other posts last year about this from people near the lakes, and wondered if they've noticed it getting even worse. Or perhaps you've all just got mosquito nets and so they've travelled a little further this year, hence why i'm now plagued. I had discussed getting some stickleback for the lakes/bryer pond - am now going back tomorrow to my mum's house where there are hundreds in the pond and think i might do a bit of pond-dipping before heading back to barbican
summary.subject: mosquito

summary.body: Last week I opened a thread on problems with phone and broadband connection using Moorgate exchange under subject Waitrose Broadband. Later I phoned BT fault repair line - 151 - and after going through a maze of options was connected to an operator in India. After hearing my description of faults she said that it was probably the main phone socket, made an appointment for an engineer to call, warning me that if the fault proved to be the phone and not the socket,I may be charged 113. I tested socket with another phone which worked. On Monday 10th engineer phoned to confirm appointment and I told him that the faults - crackly phone and very slow download speeds - had over the weekend apparently been corrected. He explained that the exchange is moving to Blackfriars (expected completion Aug 2008) and that connection speeds will suffer.  He did not think the faults were due to connections in Barbican's nether regions. As I write the ADSL router records 160kps download ( we've had around 5.5 Megs) and 448 upload which is normal. Download speed was near normal on Sunday 9, indicating perhaps that engineers weren't working on the exchange. At no time has all this been reported on BT Broadband fault line (0800 169 0199) or in phone and email contacts with BT Broadband. We wonder if others on Moorgate exchange have experienced our problems with Broadband connection. We no longer contemplate 'migrating' to Waitrose Broadband as it would still be via Moorgate exchange. With apologies for the length of this posting: when I worked as a librarian there was 'law' 'Save the time of the reader' to be applied in all library operations.
summary.subject: Moorgate phone exchange: 020 7628 .....

summary.body: The HSBC Poultry and Princess branch - the old Midland Bank Headquarters, next to the Bank of England - closes this Friday, 20th July. This branch has one of the last great Banking Halls still in use for it's original purpose. So if you want to see it before it closes, you better go now.  If you are not a HSBC customer, don't worry, there are two entrances, one at each end of the building, you enter at one, and walk the length of the banking hall to exit at the other. The branch has been doomed since HSBC moved their headquarters to the Docklands in 2004. The offices above the hall were closed at that date, HSBC sold the building for 40m and rented the ground floor for 1m a year. It has since been sold again for 72m. Since the building is Grade 1 listed, it cannot be demolished - it's supposedly going to become a grand hotel - the Banking hall becoming the hotel lobby, with the offices above being turned into hotel rooms. The replacement HSBC branch is in an inconvenient location (for the Barbican anyway) on the corner of Queen Victoria Street and Queen Street, close to Mansion House Tube. They converted the ground floor of some offices into a branch. I wouldn't hold out much hope for any architectural interest...
summary.subject: Closure of a Grand Banking Hall - HSBC Poultry and Princess

summary.body: I was talking to a friend of mine who lives in a large block of flats in Hammersmith and the subject of service charges arose.  When I told him what my service charges were, and that Barbican residents tended to complain about service charge levels he fell about laughing - his were around 4 x higher than mine - admittedly for a larger flat.  And his was an all freehold block run by a management company controlled by the residents themselves.  Anyway his charges were around 6,000 a year, which perhaps puts into perspective some of the bleats about high service charges in the Barbican.  They did get heating and hot water within their charges, but no gardens, no daily rubbish collection and no general back-up which we seem to be able to get from the Estate office.  Just thought I would make that point to this forum.  Personally I feel we do pretty well - and no I don't work for the City of London!

summary.body: Hi - washer in one of my taps finally went on Saturday am (couldn't turn the said tap off. All a bit worrying!). Wanted to share 2 positive experiences with you all: 1. Car Park attendant - was able to lend me a hammer & a very big adjustable spanner (I only possess a small electrical screw-driver. Not much use in the circumstances!) 2. The hardware shop just past the YMCA is great! Having removed the tap (with the big spanner) I took it along to buy a new washer. One of the guys there removed the old washer (easy) and fitted the new one for me (v hard - had to use a vice + big spanner as the small nut holding the washer on was siezed), whilst the other discussed Mexico with me (his wife is apparently Mexican). It could be that they knew I was a complete novice (reminding me that I should use PTFE tape in refitting the tap & seeing the look on my face probably gave the game away!) Very strong recommendation for both of above! Taps now a speciality. Oh - and the cost? 50 pence!!!
summary.subject: Bryer Car Park Attendant & our local hardware shop

summary.body: Not only has the mains water supply been off here since 0915 yesterday, Wednesday, but as of now (0800 Thursday) nothing coming out of the hot water tap in the bathroom and a reduced flow from the cold (suggesting this is just residue left in local pipework).  Indications are that TW have not maintained enough pressure to replenish the storage tanks overnight. Meantime on a call last night to TW I was told that unless I could show more than one building was affected, the problem possibly lay with pipes/pumps on the Estate(!) There have been problems before with the mains pipework in the Moor Lane/Fore Street vicinity.  Given the numbers of those affected when these outages occur and given the proposals for redevelopment at Milton Court/Frobisher I wonder if it is time that TW surveyed the entire local mains in that vicinity to establish whether it is in a condition to support the local density of population both actual and proposed.
summary.subject: The mains water outage affecting Andrewes, Gilbert & Bra

summary.body: For those of you who are interested in what was on the school site in previous centuries, I've been doing some more research and found out the following. In the late 18th century a brewery called the Goat Brewhouse was operating. A 20 year old called Sam Whitbread starting working there, then moved to Whitbread's present site within a few years. By 1813 the Whitecross St site was a debtors' prison! It was built to separate debtors from the other prisoners who were held in Newgate, so that they (the debtors) wouldn't be led astray by hardened criminals. The medieval Jewish cemetery was further south than I thought and probably stretched from Thomas More Gardens up to Beech Street.   The dig under the marquee seems to have been completed now, although the soil being replaced is being sifted through, but there's a smaller dig opened up nearer Whitecross. No idea what's there.
summary.subject: A little more local history

summary.body: Nothing to do with Macs, rather a bit of detective work for Undercover. Last week I bought some apples labelled, both collectively and individually, as Braeburns, from Waitrose. I thought at the time that they looked pretty unlike any Braeburns I had seen before - a much too uniform deep red - but I thought, naively, that Waitrose would not have got it wrong. When I got them home it became perfectly clear from the taste and texture that they were not Braeburns, so I took them back,explained the problem, and my money was refunded without question. However, I noticed that the same apples were still on sale some days later and took it up with a member of staff who was stocking the produce shelves. I pointed out the clear difference in appearance between the loose "Braeburns" and the ones in bags, which looked as they should. His explanation was that the loose ones were grown in a different country and that was why they were different in appearance, taste and texture! When I persisted, he said he would take it up with the manager. Today the same apples were still on sale, so I'd like to know when a Braeburn is not a Braeburn!
summary.subject: Apple confusion

summary.body: Has everyone in the Barbican been added to the mailing list of the Listed Property Owners Club? A few months ago I started receiving their mailshots. Their glossy brochures shows a variety of doorways on the front - Gothic, vernacular medieval, Georgian, Tudor, Art Nouveau - but sadly no Brutalist. And their very attractive magazine has classified ads for companies that offer historic limes and mortars, gilding, pargetting (whatever that is) and sand cast lead. I'm sure there is someone in there who does hammered concrete - just have to look a bit harder . . . The covering letter referred to me as the owner of a listed property, which I suppose I am to some small degree, and I do think the magazine is pretty, but I think this 'organization' (if it really is one and not just a vehicle for marketing) is probably not particularly relevant to us in the Barbican. Not complaining - I just find it all rather amusing.
summary.subject: Listed Property Owners Club?

summary.body: I don't know if we are alone in this problem My name and address held by the DVLA don't match exactly those held by the Congestion Charging people at Coventry. The DVLA have my forenames in full; the Congestion Charging people have only room for a middle initial. The congestion charging people tell me that to resolve this I need to change my details at the DVLA. This is because the Congestion Charging computer system run by Capita, those exemplars of IT efficiency, is rubbish. I would advise anyone with a residents discount to compare the details on both systems well ahead of  the renewal time. The two need to match exactly.

summary.body: Last Sunday i was passing through the Barbican Centre and thought I'd pop along to the conservatory. I hadn't been for years and was really shocked at how decrepit the place looked. Plants were falling over, some overgrown and others dying, there appeared to be a lack of any thoughtful planting, lots of random pots strewn about the place either empty or with straggeling plats in. Very little clear labelling of the plants that there were and the few labels regarding the areas that the plants were from were embarrassingly lame, giving little real information. The cacti room was closed. I felt depressed leaving the place. My thoughts about the place appear to be reflected by the comments on Babricanliving, and it's suggested that perhaps John Tusa wants to get rid of it, and therefore has cut funding and let it fall into disprepair on purpose. This would certainly be an explanation. Have anyother residents been recently and thought the same? i think it's such a wonderful place and that it's something worth saving. With some thoughtful planting and relevant, well planned labelling it could be a real educational attraction for schools etc. as well as a little haven for those attempting to escape from the city for an hour or so. In it's present state i'd never suggest to any guest visting me on a Sunday that we go. It's an embarrasment. What can we, as residents, do. except write a letter to John Tusa?
summary.subject: conservatory
